loans.use: to pay for potato seeds and fertilizer needed for the development of the farm

loans.name: Juan Gregorio

texts.es:
Juan es un señor muy trabajador, vive junto a su esposa y su hijo de 3 años en la parroquia de Valle Hermoso, perteneciente a  Santo Domingo de los Colorados, un pueblo muy productivo y de actividad turística por la hidrografía del sector.
Juan se dedica a la venta de empanas y corviques, comenzó con su negocio desde muy joven, sus principios fueron vendiendo empanadas en las afueras de su casa en una mesa de plástico, comenta que se le hizo duro porque sentía un poco de vergüenza ya que nunca había salido a vender, luego fue mejorando, comenzó a recorrer tocando de casa en casa; ya pasado los años pudo ir ahorrando y se compró un coche ya adecuado con cocina para poder recorrer con mejor comodidad. Actualmente Juan ya lleva varios años en este negocio, negocio con el cual ha podido sacar adelante a su familia; comenta que no es un trabajo fácil ya que desde las tres de la mañana él junto con su esposa se levantan a rallar y a moler  el plátano, una tarea muy cansada, luego a partir de las seis Juan ya está en las calles vendiendo todo; incluso los fines de semana cuando existen eventos lo contratan para entregas al por mayor.
Juan no ha trabajado con créditos en ninguna institución; comenta que necesita comprarse una ralladora industrial y un procesador de alimentos para poder moler el plátano,  y as  facilitar mucho su trabajo y ahorrar tiempo. Con el crédito de Fundación Alternativa y el proyecto Kiva Juan podrá comprar lo necesario para su negocio, se siente agradecido por la ayuda prestada a los microempresarios, está seguro que su negocio crecerá y así en un futuro el podrá ampliar y abrir más negocios con la ayuda de su esposa y además dar ser una fuente de trabajo para quienes necesiten superarse.
texts.en:
Juan is a very hard working man. He lives with his wife and 3-year-old son in the parish of Valle Hermoso, part of Santo Domingo de los Colorados, a very productive town which has tourism activity because of the hydrography in the area. 

Juan works selling empanadas and corviques [fried savory snacks made of ground plantain]. He began with his business when he was very young. His beginnings were selling empanadas outside his house on a plastic table. He says that it was hard at the beginning because he felt a bit embarrassed since he had never gone out to sell anything. Later, it improved and he began to go around knocking on doors. As the years passed, he could save up and he bought a cart which he outfitted with a kitchen to be able to make his rounds more comfortably. Currently, Juan has worked some years in this business, a business which has been able to get his family ahead. He says that it is not an easy job since he, along with his wife, gets up at three in the morning to grate and grind the plantain, a very tiring job. Later, at six, Juan already is in the streets selling everything. He even does it on the weekends when there are events and he is contracted to make a bulk delivery. 

Juan has never worked with loans in any institution. He says that he needs to purchase an industrial grater and a food processor to be able to grind the plantain, and in this way make his work a lot easier and save time. With the loan from Fundación Alternativa and the Kiva project, Juan will be able to purchase what he needs for his business. He is grateful for the help offered to the small business owners. He is sure that his business will grow and in the future he will be able to expand it and open more businesses with the help of his wife, and in addition, to be a source of work for those who need to improve themselves.

loans.use: to purchase an industrial grater and a food processor to grind the plantain to save time.

loans.name: Anzhela

texts.en:
Anzhela, her husband and mother-in-law live in Hatsik village of the Shirak region. Her only son serves in the army. 

Anzhela and her husband are running a farm. It includes livestock and land cultivation. The gathered agricultural harvest they sell in the local market, and this is the only source of income for the family. 

All income and resources are used for covering family's basic needs, and nothing remains to invest in the farm. This is the reason Anzhela asks lenders for the support. She asks for this loan to purchase four piglets, potato and barley seeds, and fuel needed for organizing land cultivation work and earning income for the family. 

Because the region where their village is located is considered poor, and the unemployment rate here is very high, people face numerous difficulties in developing their businesses. Anzhela's loan has been approved within the joint initiative between SEF and Kiva, which provides loans to the underserved population of the Shirak region, to help them to access the market and earn a living.

loans.use: to pay for four piglets, potato and barley seeds, and fuel needed for organizing land cultivation work and earning income for the family

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
Manuel es un hombre de 40 años, él cuenta que gracias al crédito anterior logro comprar el terreno  donde ahora está cultivando café y banano que le genera una buena ganancia, y su familia ha logrado prosperar de una gran manera, porque antes que no había comprado el terreno su único ingreso era su salario de docente, pero ahora gracias a Dios ya tiene otro fuente. Manuel ahora solicita un nuevo crédito que lo utilizara para comprar media cuerda de terreno, donde pueda seguir cultivando banano, que ese terreno algún día lo heredan sus hijos.
Él tiene  las esperanzas de conseguir el crédito, para que su familia siga mejorando.
texts.en:
Manuel is a 40-year-old man. He says that, thanks to the previous loan, he managed to purchase the land where he is now growing coffee and bananas which generates a good income, and his family has managed to prosper greatly, since before they had bought the land, their only income was his salary as a teacher, but now, thanks to God, they have another source. Manuel now asks for another loan that will be used to purchase a plot of land, where he can continue to grow bananas, and that this land one day will be the inheritance of his children.

He has hopes of getting the loan so that his family can continue improving.

loans.use: to purchase land to grow bananas.

loans.name: Maria Natalia

texts.es:
María vive junto a su esposo y un hijo en un Recinto perteneciente a la parroquia de Valle Hermoso, ciudad de Santo Domingo; un lugar muy productivo y tranquilo, en estas tierras se produce mucho el cacao, palma y ganadería.
María es una señora muy afortunada ya que cuenta con su familia muy unida, humilde y trabajadora, siempre se dan el apoyo para salir adelante. 
Cuentan con una pequeña finca, una finca donde se respira aire puro y se percibe mucha tranquilidad. En ella tienen sembrado cacao, caña de azúcar y plátano, además cuentan con una pequeña granja de chanchitos y criadero de tilapias; María junto a su esposo se levantan muy temprano para el trabajo, limpian potreros, cosechan su cacao, dan alimentos a los chanchos y a sus tilapias; ya en las tardes luego de la cosecha se ponen a preparar pasta de chocolate y también miel de caña, una vez terminado el proceso lo empaquetan y salen al pueblo a vender estos productos. 
María comenta que ella es feliz por el apoyo de su familia y de la institución, es clienta fiel de Fundación Alternativa, se siente muy agradecida ya que con este crédito ella podrá dar mantenimiento a su finca, con ello la producción mejorará y asi con estos ingresos podrá seguir dándole la educación a su hijo.
texts.en:
María lives with her husband and son in a precinct which is part of Valle Hermoso parish, Santo Domingo city. It is a very productive and peaceful place. On this land, they produce a lot of cocoa, palm, and raise animals. 

María is a lucky woman since she has a very close, humble and hard-working family. They always support each other to get ahead.  

They have a small farm, a farm where the one breathes pure air and feels very peaceful. There, they have planted cocoa, sugar cane and plantain. In addition, they have a small farm with pigs and a tilapia nursery. María, with her husband, gets up very early to work. They clean pastures, harvest the cocoa, and feed the pigs and tilapia. In the afternoons, after harvesting, they work preparing the chocolate spread and also cane syrup. Once finished with the process, they package it and go to town to sell these products. 

María says that she is happy for the support of her family and the institution. She is a loyal client of Fundación Alternativa, she feels very grateful since with this loan she will be able to maintain her farm, and with it the production will improve and with this income, she will be able to continue providing her son with an education.

loans.use: to maintain her farm and improve her production and in this way provide an education for her son.

loans.name: Andrey

texts.en:
Andrey is married and has two daughters. His wife is on maternity leave. Andrey used to work as a hired employee; some time ago the owner of the business sold it to him.

Andrey cuts and sells glass, mirrors and tables made of glass. He has the best prices in the city. Andrey is advertising his workshop, hoping to attract more customers and increase the income. He is a responsible, active and open person.

Andrey is asking for a loan of 40,000 UAH to buy glass and other materials for the workshop. The loan will help him to make new, good quality products.

loans.use: to buy glass and other materials for his workshop

loans.name: Ilham

texts.en:
Ilham is a 50-year-old married woman from a village near Ramallah. She is the mother of one son and three daughters. She has worked sewing clothes in her house for many years; she has very good experience. But Ilham has a very old machine which make her productivity very slow. She earns a very low income now and does not cover her family needs.

Ilham took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her to buy a new machine for her sewing work; this will increase her productivity and also her income.

Ilham appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new machine for her sewing work.

loans.name: Ala

texts.en:
Ala got a university education and graduated many years ago. Due to the high rate of unemployment, he couldn't find a job to look after of his family. With the financial support of his father, Ala has started his own business selling various kinds of food materials (canned foods and soft drinks) and other items in a small grocery in Haja, Yemen. That grocery store is the sole source of income for Ala and his family. Its capital is small, and Ala strives strongly to increase it. 

For this reason, he applied for a youth loan of 200,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase different kinds of food materials for his grocery to expand his business. With this loan, Ala will be able to provide his business with goods that are not founded inside the grocery, and that will help him to attract a lot of customers. Taking this loan will enable Ala to provide his family with a good living condition.

Ala looks forward to purchasing a vehicle to use in his business.

loans.use: To purchase different kinds of food materials for his grocery to expand his business

loans.name: Nial

texts.en:
Nial is a 27-year-old married man from Beddya, a village near Nablus city. He is a father for one son and one daughter. Two years ago, Nial started his job as a construction worker. It is a very good business, but seasonal; the demand in the winter is very low. 

Nial took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy some construction supplies for his work. This will increase his productivity and also his income. 

Nial appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy some construction supplies for his work.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 23-year-old single man from Khan Younis city. He wants to start his own business and be independent, so he decided to open a grocery store. Ibrahim has the store, but he wants now to buy some inventory.

Ibrahim took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy grocery products for his new store. 

This will enable him to start his own business. 

Ibrahim appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy grocery products for his new store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy grocery products for his store.

loans.name: Kamini Group

texts.en:
Kamini Self Help Group (SHG) was formed in January 2015 consisting of 10 rural, poor women belonging to the Below Poverty Line population. This group is located in a remotely rural village named Chanutmal of Nuapada district of Odisha, India. 

Vegetable cultivation and vending is the primary source of livelihood of most of the members of this group. Pratima is one of them. The lady standing in the middle with a raised hand in the photo is Pratima. She is a very energetic lady of 32 years of age living with her husband, one son of 8 years and one daughter of 4 years. Her son is reading in 3rd standard.

Pratima has a vegetable cultivation farm of 1 hectare. Her husband manages the farm. Her husband is an active and cheerful farmer. He produces vegetables like brinjal, cauliflower, carrots, cabbage, chilies, cucumbers, papayas, ladies finger, onions, etc., in the farm and sells the products to the traders of nearby towns who come to take vegetables from the farm.  

Apart from that Pratima herself is running a general store in her house. Her husband helps her in bringing items like lentils, soap, shampoo, sugar, potatoes, onions, biscuits, etc., from the nearest town of 15 kilometers away. 

She says that she earns a minimum amount of 5,000 INR per month from this business, which is insufficient to meet the day-to-day expenses of her family, farm expenses and business investment. 

Pratima wants to expand her business by taking a loan from Kiva through her SHG from Mahashakti Foundation. She has planned to utilize the present loan to buy a water pump for her farm and purchase lentils for her general store. She expects a good return from this investment. 

Pratima dreams to construct a house for her family and give better education to her children. She also hopes to give her whole family a bright future through her hard work. The other nine members of the SHG are doing ground nut cultivation and want to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to purchase lentils for the general store and a water pump for the vegetable farm.

loans.name: Rodrigo

texts.en:
"Sounds good" isn’t just a phrase that Rodrigo uses; it’s become a way of life for him. Since he was a child, he has always loved cooking for his family and working with his hands. While he was living in Colombia for school for three years, he fell in love with the cuisine and got the inspiration for a food cart that serves good Colombian-inspired food, unlike anything you could find in the States. 

After working as a respiratory therapist for many years, he decided to follow his passion and start his food cart. Named Algo Bueno, which means "Sounds Good" in Spanish, his business perpetuates the "good" lifestyle.

He draws much of his inspiration from Latin and Colombian cuisines. His menu highlights the Arepa, which is a flatbread made of ground maize dough or cooked flour. He will sell his fusion food with his business partner and mother of his two children at farmers markets and street fairs around the San Diego area. 

“I am a very humble person, and I have the drive and passion for my new business,” stated Rodrigo. “I want to make an impact on people and know that I am providing good food for families to come eat.” 

He will use his Kiva loan to pay for his final permits and also to purchase his start-up inventory. He wants Kiva lenders to know how grateful he is to be able to follow his culinary dreams and provide for his family.

loans.use: to pay for his final permits and also to purchase his start-up inventory.

loans.name: Maa Dhareni Shg-F Group

texts.en:
The group Maa Dhareni SHG-F has 10 members who are all from the same neighborhood, and here, only two members are highlighted. The lady standing on the right side in the photo is Tula. She is the featured borrower of the group. Tula is a 36-year-old woman married to a farmer. The couple has three children who are in school. Tula lives with her children and, together with her husband, takes care of all the household expenses. 

In order to help with all the family expenses, Tula has been involved in doing paddy (rice) cultivation and selling it to distributors for the past 12 years. She supplies her rice to the rice dealers in the nearby market. In order to strengthen the business and respond to client demand, Tula, together with the group member Sobhai, is requesting a loan from Peoples Forum to purchase fertilizers, pesticides, and seeds and to cover operational costs. Their goal is to increase their business activities.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, pesticides, and seeds

loans.name: Maa Raudi Devi Shg-A Group

texts.en:
Padma, Chandri and Koushalya belong to an 11-member group, Maa Raudi Devi SHG-A. Padma is a 41-year-old lady living with her husband and three children. In the picture, the lady standing in middle in the photo is Padma. She owns and manages a dairy farm, where she has a few cows and buffaloes. She sells 10 liters of milk per day and earns 8,000 INR per month. Her monthly income is very small for a family of five persons, as her children are in school. She wants to purchase two Jersey cows for her farm, as demand for cow's milk is high in her village. She also has a plan to repair the shed for her cattle and make it bigger. 

Padma, along with her group members, has requested a loan of 54,000 INR. She will use her portion of the loan for purchasing two cows and renovating the shed. In the future, she wants to expand her farm and sell more milk products like yogurt, butter, etc. She has a dream to give a quality life to her family and save some money for her children's future. All the members of this group are engaged in the dairy business.

loans.use: to pay for two cows and renovating the cattle shed.

loans.name: Maa Raudi Devi Shg-B Group

texts.en:
Chanchala, the lady standing on the right side in the photo, is 35 years old and married. She has two children who are both in school. Her family lives in a village of the Koraput District in Odisha, India. She and her husband earn a living through working as farmers and cultivating rice and vegetables. Having been in this business for seven years, she is able to earn approximately 4,000 INR per month to meet her family’s needs. 

Chanchala is leading a group named Maa Raudi Devi Shg-B. Its two members are applying for the loan with Peoples' Forum. Both the members are engaged in different kind of activities like agriculture and a general store. 

Chanchala is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers, seeds, pesticides and some irrigation tools for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to raise more crops and sell them for a good price to make a better living to send her children to a good school.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds, pesticides and some irrigation tools for her farmland.

loans.name: Maa Raudi Devi Shg-C Group

texts.en:
In 2014, a group of two women came together from a small village in Koraput district, Odisha, and formed Maa Raudi Devi SHG-C. Padmani was selected as the featured borrower of the group. The lady standing on the left side in the photo is Padmani. 

Padmani is 31 years old, married, and living with her husband and two children. She has been involved in a milk business for eight years. She has one cow, and she wants to purchase one more cow because the demand for milk is high, and she is not able to supply the growing demand of the customers in the market. 

She has applied for a loan to purchase a cow and fodder, and also wants to repair her cattle shed. This business will help her to support her children's education. She says that this loan can help to increase her income, which will help her to purchase the study materials for her children's education and to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and fodder for her milk business.

loans.name: Manegre 13 Sapone Group

texts.fr:
Mr ETIENNE  est responsable du groupe  MANEGRE 13 SAPONE. Il est marié et père de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 08 ans et le moins  âgé a 06 ans. 02 enfants vont à l’école et il a 03 personnes en charge.
Monsieur fait de l’élevage depuis 12 ans. Il s’approvisionne dans  les  marchés environnants.
Avec l’argent octroyé, il compte acheter 04 porcs.
Il veut utiliser les bénéfices du prêt pour réinvestir dans son activité. Il ambitionne  assurer l’avenir de ses enfants.
texts.en: Etienne is the head of the Manegre 13 Sapone Group. He is a married father to two children. His eldest is eight years old and his youngest is six years old. Both his children are currently receiving an education and he has three people living within his care. Etienne has been raising livestock for the past 12 years. He gets his stock from the local markets. With this loan, he plans on purchasing four pigs. He wants to reinvest the profits from this loan back into his business. He hopes to be able to pay for his children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase four pigs

loans.name: Manegre 01 Sapone Group

texts.fr:
Mr SIBIRI est responsable du groupe  MANEGRE 01 DE SAPONE. Il est marié et père de 09 enfants. Le plus âgé a 28 ans et le moins âgé a 03 mois. 06 enfants vont à l’école et il a 14 personnes en charge.
Monsieur fait de l’élevage depuis 25 ans. Il s’approvisionne dans  les  marchés environnants.
Avec l’argent octroyé, il compte acheter 04 moutons.
Il veut utiliser les bénéfices du prêt pour réinvestir dans son activité. Il ambitionne assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en: Sibiri is the head of the Manegre 01 Sapone Group. He is a married father to nine children. His eldest is 28 years old and his youngest is three months old. Six of his children are currently receiving an education and he has 14 people living within his care. Sibiri has been raising livestock for the past 25 years. He gets his stock from the local markets. With this loan, he plans on purchasing four sheep. He wants to reinvest the profits from this loan back into his business. He hopes to be able to pay for his children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase four sheep

loans.name: Bernardina

texts.es:
Bernardina es una señora amable y solidaria, tiene cuarenta y cuatro años, vive en una comunidad de San Pablo Jocopilas,  tiene una linda familia de cuatro hijos de las edades entre 19 y 25 años de edad.
Bernardina para apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa, vende tortillas  en su aldea, ella realiza esta actividad desde hace cinco años, pero para poder mejorar sus ingresos trabaja también lavando ropas ajenas  con el que obtiene un poco más de ingresos.
Bernardina  ahora ha tenido la iniciativa de construir un local donde en el futuro pueda instalar una tienda de compra y venta de abarrotes, pero una de las dificultades que Bernardina tiene es que no cuenta con el capital para empezar la construcción, por tal razón ella solicita un crédito que lo utilizara para comprar cemento, bloc, arena, hierro y piedrín.
Ella guarda las esperanzas de conseguir el crédito y poder construir su local para que pueda tener otro fuente de ingresos con la instalación de su tienda.
texts.en:
Bernardina is a kind and caring lady. She is 44 years old. She lives in the community of San Pablo Jocopilas. She has a lovely family of four children between the ages of 19 and 25 years of age. 

In order to help her husband with the household expenses she sells tortillas in her village. She has been doing this activity for five years but in order to improve her income she also has another job washing clothes with which she gets a bit more income.

Bernardina has now taken the initiative to construct a facility where in the future she can open a store so she can buy and sell groceries, but one of the difficulties that Bernandina has is that she does not have the capital to start construction. This is why she is asking for a loan to use to buy cement, blocks, sand, iron and gravel.

She is harboring the hope of getting a loan so she can construct a place where she can have another source of income by setting up her store.

loans.use: to buy cement, blocs, sand, iron, and gravel in order to construct a place where she can set up a store

loans.name: Maa Raudi Devi Shg-D Group

texts.en:
Maa Raudi Devi SHG-D was formed with two members in 2014 in a small village in Odisha. They came together to help each other and solve the social issues between them, save money and provide financial support to their families. They chose Raimati as the featured borrower of their group. The lady standing left side in the photo is Raimati. 

Raimati is a 34-year-old woman living with her husband and her three children. For seven years, Raimati's husband has been working as a farmer to support his small family. His income is not sufficient to support the family, so Raimati is helping her husband by working with him and being involved in the mushroom cultivating business. She has four years of experience in this business. 

She has requested a loan to buy more mushroom seeds, straw and other materials, and to repair the space where her mushrooms are cultivated, so that she can add to her family’s income. Raimati says that by selling mushrooms, she can support her family, and she can send her children to a good school. Through that, she can provide a better education to her children.

loans.use: to purchase mushroom seeds, straw and other raw materials, and to repair the space where her mushrooms are cultivated.

loans.name: Maa Raudi Devi Shg-E Group

texts.en:
Sanai is 33 years old and married. In the picture, the lady standing left side in the photo is Sanai. She lives in a village in the Koraput district with her husband and her two children. 

She and her husband earn a living by farming rice and vegetables. Having been in this business for 11 years, she manages to earn about 5,000 INR per month. 

This is a group loan for Sanai's group of two women called Maa Raudi Devi SHG-E. She is leading her group to apply for a loan. Sanai wants to use her loan portion to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland. She hopes to increase her rice yield and earn more income to better her living conditions.

The members of the group are very ambitious and are engaged in different kinds of activities.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Shg- 9A Group

texts.en:
Maa Mangala SHG-9A was formed in 2014 and is composed of two members in a small village in Odisha. Chandra is the lady who is standing left side in the photograph. Chandra, age 25, is an educated member of their group, so she was selected as the leader as well as featured borrower of this group. 

Chandra has one son, age 5 years. She is living with her husband and her son. With the loan that she is receiving, Chandra plans to boost her agricultural business, and to do so, she will purchase chemical fertilizers, rent a field and pay for the cost of labor. In order to strengthen her agricultural business, she plans to improve her strategy and make use of new farming techniques. Both Chandra and her husband have been involved in this activity for 15 years. They have good knowledge of paddy rice cultivation and vegetable cultivation. Chandra currently grows rice. 

She, along with Subhagya, has requested a loan to expand her agriculture activity. Her ambition is to enlarge the business for which she is receiving financial support and to diversify her activity by growing vegetables.

loans.use: to purchase chemical fertilizers, rent a field and pay for the cost of labor.

loans.name: Cfjdt 53 Group

texts.fr: CFJDT 53 est un sous groupe de la Convergence des Femmes et Jeunes pour le Développement de Tassette. Il est composé de 5 personnes dont 4 femmes et un homme. Ils habitent à un village qui est à quelques kilomètres du Village de Tassette. Ils font les mêmes activités et se réunissent à chaque de fin de mois pour organiser des tontines et discuter sur les moyens stratégiques pour le développement de leur village et lutter contre la pauvreté. La présidente s'appelle COUMBFA, elle est reconnue sur la photo par la main levée. Elle est mariée et mère de famille qui aide son mari dans la gestion des dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et les frais de scolarités de ses enfants. Elle sollicite ce montant pour acheter des bœufs dans les marchés hebdomadaires, les élever et  les revendre dans le village. Elle a une expérience de plus de 20 ans dans cette activité. Elle commence sa journée à 6h pour la terminer à 18h. A l'avenir elle voudrait avoir une ferme agricole ainsi elle pourra augmenter ses revenus et diversifier ses produits en important des bœufs venant d'Europe.
texts.en:
CFJDT 53 is a sub-group of the Gathering of Women and Young People for the Development of Tassette. The group is made up of five persons, four women and one man. They live in a villiage which is situated a few kilometers from the village of Tassette. They have the same businesses and they meet once at the end of every month to organize revolving loan accounts and discuss strategic means for the development of their village and to struggle against poverty. 

The president is called Coumba; she is raising her hand in the photo. She is married and mother of a family and she helps her husband cover the daily expenses of the family and the school fees of her children. She is requesting this amount to buy some cows in the weekly markets to raise and sell in the village. She has 20 years' experience in this business. Her day begins at 6 am and ends at 6 pm. In future she would like to have a farm for agriculture so that she could grow her income and diversify her products by importing cows from Europe.

loans.use: to buy cows to raise and sell later on

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy grocery goods.

loans.name: Annastasia

texts.en:
Annastasia is 56 years old now. She is married and blessed with five children. 

Annastasia is runs a food stall as well as farming business which she has done for 30 years earning a monthly income being KES 8,000.She is taking her second loan with VisionFund Kenya after successfully repaying her previous loan. 

She plans to use the entire loan to purchase fertilizer and seedlings for planting during this season. She plans to use the generated profits to pay school fees for her children. 

In the future Annastasia looks forward to being self sustainable.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Artyom

texts.en:
This young man is 22 years old, and his name is Artyom. He lives in the frontier village of Heghut of the Tavush region. He is not married, and he lives with his mother, brother and grandmother. With his brother, he works all day long in order to provide their family with normal living conditions. He used to do different construction work in his village, but now he decided to develop farming. 

In his farm, Artyom has cows and bulls. The main products for sale are milk, meat and cheese that his grandmother makes. Artyom is satisfied neither with his farm's smallness nor its income.

With this deal with Kiva lenders, he hopes to have more income; he plans to buy several calves for his farm and also animal fodder for his farm cattle. He thinks that his farm enlargement is a good way of having more profit and improving his family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to buy several calves for his farm and also animal fodder for his farm cattle

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
Karine is farmer from Vanashen village, Ararat region. She lives there with her two sons, daughter-in-law, grandson and sister-in-law. 

Karine runs a farm. She cultivates tomatoes and garlic and keeps hens. She also keeps an orchard where she grows fruit trees (apricot, apple and grape).
 
All the available resources are used for survival and nothing remains to invest in a farming business. As the children grow up, the family need more and more resources to have the ends meet. 

Karine has applied for this loan to purchase fertilizer and cultivation work and hire workers for cultivation work. Karine has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to pay it back. However, thanks to her hard work during recent times, Karine was able to run her agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. 

Karine will wait for lenders' support and hopes that this loan will help her in developing her farm.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizer and cultivation work and hire workers for cultivation work

loans.name: Maa Mangala Shg 9E Group

texts.en:
A portion of this group loan will go to support Sunamani. She is the featured borrower of Maa Mangala SHG 9E and is pictured here as the lady standing left side in the photo. The second women in her group is also working in dairy farming. 

Sunamani belongs to a very small village in Koraput district of Odisha state, a state on the eastern coast of India. With her portion of the loan, Sunamani will buy more cows to increase her dairy farming business. After this loan, Sunamani will be able to be more independent and help give her family a better standard of living. Sunamani is an entrepreneur at heart and has big dreams of one day owning a large dairy farm. 

The second women in the group plans to save the money she earns from expanding her business to buy a food-processing machine that they can both use to make spices and pickle vegetables together.

loans.use: to purchase more cows to increase her dairy farming business.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Shg 9F Group

texts.en:
The women of the Maa Mangala SHG 9F are from a small village in the Koraput district in Odisha in the eastern part of the India. The group is composed of two women who earn their living by selling milk and cultivating and selling vegetables. They need additional capital to maintain, enhance or expand their businesses and decided to apply for a loan with People's Forum. They are excited and full of hope to begin this new season with solid goals and dreams. 

Puspanjali is a 45-year-old mother of two children. In the picture, the lady standing right side in the photo is Puspanjali. She completed three years of formal education but, due to the poor economic condition of her family, had to leave her education behind. Along with all the clients of People's Forum, Puspanjali realizes that education is a vital key to a successful future for her children. She says that her business is running quite well and, because of its success, she will be able to register her children in a good school this year. 

Puspanjali is engaged in vegetable cultivation and she produces potatoes, tomatoes, onions, and seasonal vegetables. 

Puspanjali is applying for her first loan with People's Forum. The requested funds will be used to purchase standard quality seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for her vegetable cultivation. With an optimistic spirit and positive attitude, Puspanjali looks forward to this new season with its challenges, blessings and successes. On behalf of her colleagues, Puspanjali expresses gratitude and appreciation for the help from Kiva investors throughout the world who lend such necessary and vital support.

loans.use: To purchase standard quality seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for her vegetable cultivation.

loans.name: Tinatin

texts.en:
Tinatin is 37 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and two children in Ozurgeti district. The family owns a plot of land, where they grow maize and nut trees to sell locally at a good price. They also own two cows and produce dairy products. 

As the income is only seasonal and not enough to cover the expenses of a four-member family, Tinatin decided to start a business. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of 3,000 GEL. Tinatin will purchase gas containers and will place them in a family-owned minibus. In their district, there is no gas installed in the houses, so she will fill up the big containers and help her villagers to charge their small gas balloons, which are used mainly for cooking. 

Part of the profit will be reinvested in the same business, and another part will be used to cultivate more land and plant more vegetables. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase gas containers and charge gas balloons

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 23-year-old man from Haja, Yemen, who sells water pump spare parts in a small store. He applied to Al-Amal Microfinance Bank to take a youth loan of 300,000 YER to purchase a small solar module for his house. 

The electricity is off most of these days because of the hard situation inside the country. In the beginning, Ali thought of purchasing a power generator but there is a severe shortage of both oil and diesel. Purchasing the solar module is the best way to have good lighting for his house when the is power off. By this loan, the living condition of his family will improve and the family will live without darkness. Purchasing the solar module will make all his neighbors consider buying one as a way to get light with minimal cost.
 
Ali looks forward to opening a solar modules store to sell them alongside water pump spare parts.

loans.use: To purchase a small solar module for his house.

loans.name: Danusya

texts.en:
Danusya is a 49-year-old farmer from Lernakert village in the Shirak region. She lives with her husband and daughter. Her primary business is running her family farm where she keeps cows, calves, sheep and hens. Danusya also cultivates wheat and barley. She has many years of experience and many goals for expanding her farm.

The Shirak region, where she and her family live and work, is considered a poor region where the unemployment rate is very high and living standards are quite low. Lack of access to loan products, bad market conditions, and high costs combine to make it difficult for people to develop their area businesses. 

Danusya is requesting a loan to pay for seed and forage for feeding her livestock. Her request has been approved within a joint initiative between SEF International and Kiva to provide loans to the underserved population of the Shirak region to help them access markets and earn better livings. Danusya and her family hope to receive lender support and develop their farming business further.

loans.use: to pay for seed and forage to feed her livestock

loans.name: Maa Mangala Shg 9B Group

texts.en:
Maa Mangala SHG 9B consists of two women from a village in Odisha. They formed this group to share their problems and to solve their problems themselves. 

One of the members is Nila, who is a widow. She was selected as the featured borrower of this group. The lady standing left side in the photo is Nila. Nila is 45 years old and is staying with her her three children. She is involved in growing and selling vegetables in her village. Her children are supporting her in this activity. 

Her group has requested a loan of 36,000 INR and she will use her portion to purchase the required resources for vegetable cultivation. She says her portion of the loan will help her to purchase vegetable seeds, fertilizers and insecticides, and to cover operational expenses like labor charges.

loans.use: to purchase vegetable seeds, fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Shg 9C Group

texts.en:
From a small village in the Koraput district, Odisha state, India, two women stepped out and made a self-help group having the name of "Maa Mangala SHG 9C" to earn some money from different activities to support their families. The group members are engaged in paddy cultivation and vegetable cultivation. 

Parbati, age 32, is a married lady with two children. The lady standing left side in the photo is Parbati. To provide a living, she has been planting rice and farming for seven years. From farming, she earns an income of 3,500 INR per month. Now, she is the featured borrower of this group, and they are seeking their first loan with People's Forum (Kiva’s partner) for 36,000 INR. 

As the featured borrower, she is going to use her loan portion to buy rice seeds and fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes she will have a good rice crop yield to earn a profit to support her business.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds and fertilizer for her farmland.

loans.name: Sougrenooma De Yamtenga Group

texts.fr: Mamouna est la responsable de ce groupe de 3 femmes battantes. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont 3 sont scolarisés. Elle vend des légumes et du soumbala, un produit burkinabé très utilisé. En effet, le soumbala est fait à base des grains de neeré et utilisé par les malades de tension et même les personnes bien portantes. Mamouna a besoin de ce crédit pour acheter des légumes et du soumbala pour vendre à ses clients. Cette brave a un employé qui l'aide dans son commerce. A l'issue de ses ventes, son bénéfice lui permettra d'aider son époux à faire les dépenses de la famille et de continuer son activité.
texts.en: Mamouna is the head of this group of three courageous women. She is a married mother to five children, three of whom are currently receiving an education. She sells vegetables and soumbala, a common condiment from Burkina Faso. Soumbala is made from a base of locust bean seeds and is used to treat blood pressure ailments. It is also consumed by healthy people. Mamouna needs this loan in order to purchase vegetables and soumbala which will then be resold to her customers. This brave woman employs an assistant who helps her run this business. Once she has sold her stock, the profits will allow her to support her husband with their family's expenses and allow her to carry on her business.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables and soumbala (a common condiment from Burkina Faso) which will then be resold

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chicken feeds

loans.name: Grigor

texts.en:
Grigor lives with his nice family in Dilijan city, which is in the Tavush region. Grigor says that he greatly enjoyed his two previous deals with Kiva and hopes for the third one. He hopes that Kiva lenders will be so kind again to support him in his request with the loan amount. 

Grigor works at the computer office, and there he repairs computers and printing machines. His wife also works there as a manager. Grigor has two pretty daughters; the elder already graduated from a state university, and she works at the insurance company. The smallest daughter is still a student at the Yerevan State University, at the faculty of Romano and Germanic languages. She studies at the paid division and Grigor would like to solve the problem of tuition fee repayment again with the help of Kiva lenders. 

This loan of 450,000 Armenian drams he seeks as he must pay his smallest daughter’s tuition fee.

loans.use: to pay his smallest daughter’s tuition fee

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow and farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy beans to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fertilizer for rice.

loans.name: Lilit

texts.en:
This young woman in the photo is Lilit from Haykasar village of the Shirak region. She lives there with her husband and two children (two daughters, 7 and 5 years old).
 
To help her husband with the family's daily needs, Lilit got involved in the farming business. Her husband is a migrant seasonal worker and all income from his work is hardly enough for covering the family's basic costs. 

Agribusiness helps them a lot. Lilit used to work at a local village school, but because of the low salary, she decided to develop the farming business.
 
The Shirak region is considered a poor region where the unemployment rate is very high and living standards are quite low. Lack of access to loan products, bad market conditions, and high costs make up a number of difficulties for people to develop their businesses in the area. Lilit's loan has been approved within the joint initiative between SEF International and Kiva, which provides loans to the underserved population of the Shirak region to help them access markets and earn a better living.

Lilit and her family are looking forward to your support to feed the cattle and boost their farming business.

loans.use: to pay for forage for feeding the cattle

loans.name: Silva

texts.en:
The sunny woman in this photo is Silva, who is from Saralanj village in the Shirak region. She is a farmer who lives with her mother-in-law, two sons, and husband.  Silva’s sons and husband are seasonal migrant workers, but during the time they are at home, they help Silva to farm. Together, the family enriches their farm which currently includes cows, calves, and hens as well crops of potato, carrots and garlic. 

The Shirak region, where Silva and her family live and work, is considered a poor region where the unemployment rate is very high and living standards are quite low. Lack of access to loan products, bad market conditions, and high costs combine to make it difficult for people to develop their area businesses. 

Silva is requesting a loan to purchase potato and barley seed as well as forage for feeding her livestock. Her request has been approved within a joint initiative between SEF International and Kiva to provide loans to the underserved population of the Shirak region to help them access markets and earn better livings. Silva’s loan will be a big support for her farming business.

loans.use: to purchase potato and barley seed and livestock forage

loans.name: Ruzanna

texts.en:
Ruzanna lives in Saratak village of the Shirak region with her husband and son. She and her family are farmers and they run a farm where she keeps cows, calves, and hens.  Ruzanna also cultivates wheat and potatoes and her husband and son work growing and selling flowers. 

The Shirak region, where Ruzanna and her family live and work, is considered a poor region where the unemployment rate is very high and living standards are quite low. Lack of access to loan products, bad market conditions, and high costs combine to make it difficult for people to develop their area businesses. 

Ruzanna is requesting a loan to purchase potato seed and forage to feed her livestock. Her loan will help develop her farm. Ruzanna's request has been approved within a joint initiative between SEF International and Kiva to provide loans to the underserved population of the Shirak region to help them access markets and earn better livings. Ruzanna hopes to receive lender support to develop her farming business and provide better living conditions to her family.

loans.use: to pay for potato seeds and livestock forage

loans.name: Maa Mangala Shg 9D Group

texts.en:
Purba is a 33-year-old lady who lives with her husband and two children, ages 9 and 7, in a small village in the Koraput district, Odisha, India. In the picture, the lady standing left side in the photo is Purba. She is engaged in paddy cultivation. Her husband is doing the same business. 

Some years ago, Purba formed a group with other women from her village and named the group Maa Mangala SHG 9D. Both the members are engaged in business activities of selling milk and cultivating vegetables to alleviate their poverty. Purba is the featured borrower of this group. She motivated Dutika to form this group so they could help and support each other in their business and personal lives. 

Purba will use her portion to purchase standard-quality seeds and fertilizers for her paddy cultivation. She hopes to build a house for her family, and she is very grateful to Kiva for this opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase standard-quality seeds and fertilizers for her paddy (rice) cultivation.

loans.name: Vololona

texts.fr:
Vololona est une femme de 37 ans. Elle vit dans la commune urbaine d’Antsirabe avec son mari et ses 3 enfants. Elle est commerçante et vend de la vaisselle et des ustensiles de cuisine au grand marché de la ville. Vololona est toujours souriante et est réputée pour l’accueil chaleureux qu’elle réserve  à ses clients.

Elle est partenaire de Vahatra depuis 3 ans ce qui lui a permis de diversifier les articles qu’elle propose et de pouvoir également s’orienter vers la vente de marmites qui nécessite effectivement un capital plus important. Grâce à ce prêt, elle compte continuer d’augmenter son stock de marchandises et acheter des marmites de taille diverse, cuvettes...

Cela fait 10 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité et grâce aux bénéfices perçus, la famille a pu acheter une petite maison. Son objectif désormais est de pouvoir en faire les finitions tout en continuant à assurer l’éducation et l’avenir de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Vololona is a woman of 37 years of age. She lives in the urban area of Antsirabe with her husband and their three children. She is a small-scale trader and sells dishes and kitchen utensils in a market in the town. Vololona is always smiling and is known for the hearty welcome she reserves for her customers. 

She has been a partner of Vahatra for three years which has allowed her to diversify the merchandise she offers and also be able to sell cooking pots, which necessitates a bigger working capital. Thanks to this loan, she intends to continue to grow her inventory and buy various cooking pots and basins and such. 

She has been in this business for 10 years and thanks to the profit she has made, the family has been able to buy a little house. Her goal from now on is to be able to put the finishing touches on it while continuing to ensure the education and the future of her children.

loans.use: to buy a stock of kitchen utensils such as pots, basins and salad bowls.

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Sali est la femme à droite posant sa main gauche sur le bœuf.
Sali est une malienne,  âgée de 36 ans et éleveur de bœufs  mère de 07 enfants dont l’aine  a 17 ans , 04 sont scolarisés et 03 non scolarises, elle n’a pas eu  une chance d’aller à l’école elle fait cette  activité depuis 06 ans.
Son mari est un cultivateur dévoué  dans son activité, Sali n’ayant pas assez  de fonds, elle a fait recourt à L’IMF  pour avoir plus de fonds  pour acheter plus de bœufs pour l’élever
Elle rêve dans les jours à venir d’avoir ses propres fonds  pour être indépendante  dans  son activité.
Elle s’approvisionne dans les foires de la localité et fait la distribution dans les mêmes foires de la localité, elle est souvent confronté  à    quelques obstacles tel que la mévente et la surproduction, la chute des prix. Elle réalise un bénéfice prévisionnel de 80000f par cycle de prêts.
texts.en:
Sali is the woman on the right, with her left hand on the cow. She is from Mali, aged 36, and raises cattle. She is a mother of seven children of whom the eldest is 17. Four of them are enrolled in school and three not in school. Sali did not have the good fortune to attend school, and she has been in this business for six years. Her husband is a farmer who is devoted to his activity. 

Since she does not have enough funds, Sali came to the Microfinance Institution to have more working capital to buy cattle to raise. She dreams that in the future she will have enough of her own money to be independent in her activity. She stocks up in the weekly fairs in the area and  sells in the same local fair. She is often confronted with challenges such as a slump in sales and over-production, falling prices. She expects to make a profit of 80,000 francs for each loan cycle.

loans.use: to buy a cow to raise and sell later.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a 24-year-old single man in Dier El Balah city. He lives with his family in a small simple house. He started his own business one year ago when he opened a grocery store in his neighborhood.

Mohammad took a USD Murabaha loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy grocery products for his store. This will enable him to increase his sales and also his income. 

Mohammad appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy grocery products for his store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Jiguène Bakhna 50 Group

texts.fr: Jiguène Bakhna 50 fait parti de l'Association des Jeunes et Femmes Commerçantes. Il est composé de 4 femmes et un homme. Ils habitent tous dans le même village et font des activités différentes comme le commerce, l'aviculture et la restauration. Ils se réunissent tous les fins de mois pour organiser des tontines. Madame AMY est la présidente, c'est une femme mariée et mère de famille. Elle évolue dans le restaurant, elle a une expérience de plus de 5 ans. Elle sollicite ce montant pour acheter des produits, des denrées et des légumes pour la préparation de ses plats du jour comme de nuit. Elle commence sa journée à 6h pour la terminer à 22h. Avec les bénéfices elle va aider son mari dans la gestion des dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et les frais de scolarité de ses enfants. Elle souhaite avec l'aide de l'institution augmenter ses employés afin de pouvoir augmenter ses revenus et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille
texts.en:
The Jiguène Bakhna 50 group is a part of the Association of Young and Female Merchants (l'Association des Jeunes et Femmes Commerçantes). It is made up of four women and one man. 

The group members all live in the same village and work in commerce, poultry farming, and the restaurant business. They meet at the end of every month to organize the savings group. 

Amy is the president. She is married and a mother of a family. She has worked in the restaurant business for more than five years. She is seeking a loan to buy goods, foodstuffs, and vegetables so that she can prepare daytime and nighttime meals. She starts her day at 6 a.m. and finishes at 10 p.m.

With her earnings, she is going to help her husband take care of the family's everyday expenses and to pay her children's school fees. 

She wishes, with the help of the institution [UIMCEC], to increase the number of her employees so that she can increase her revenues and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and foodstuffs for her restaurant business

loans.name: Group Bunda Swala

texts.en:
Pamela, who is in her late 30s, is a widow with four kids: one son and three daughters. They are all still in school. She has been selling clothes for ten years now. She works from 7 am to 8 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Pamela's 5th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase on the clothes stock and has paid back all her loans successfully. She used the profit to pay school fees, loan repayment and covered household expenses. She will use this loan to buy up-to-date clothes to meet her customers' requirements. She dreams of opening a very big clothes shop.

Pamela will share this loan with her loan group, Group Bunda Swala, which has two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy up-to-date clothes to meet her customers' requirements.

loans.name: El Cerro Group

texts.es: Tres mujeres laboriosas solicitan por octavo ciclo el financiamiento para sus negocios con el objetivo de incrementar el capital de sus negocios, quien lo coordina es la señora Brenda que tiene la edad de 30 años, acompañada y madre de un hijo de la edad de 5 años quien ha sido su mayor motivación para conseguir su superación, ella ofrece el servicio de venta de comida en su domicilio desde hace dos años, los créditos anteriores le han permitido realizar mejoras en su vivienda, lo que la ha motivado para mejorar la situación familiar por medio de su negocio, el crédito actual lo solicita para la compra de granos básicos como es arroz, frijol, aceite, salsa de tomate, repollo, lechuga, utensilios para la cocina, etc., de manera que le permitirá seguir ofreciendo un servicio de calidad. Las demás integrantes son las señoras, Maritza una señora ejemplar que a sus 50 años es propietaria de una mini pulpería, y Juana que tiene la edad de 37 años y ofrece en su domicilio helados, hielo y refresco desde hace ocho años.
texts.en:
Three hard-working women are requesting their 8th loan for their businesses with the aim of increasing the capital of their businesses. Brenda is the coordinator. She is 30 years old, is in a relationship and the mother of a five year old who is her major motivation to continue to excel. She has been offering food for sale from her house for the past 2 years.

The previous loans have allowed her to make improvements on her house. This has motivated her to improve the family's financial situation through her business. This loan being requested will be used to buy basic grains like rice, beans, oil, tomato paste, cabbage, lettuce, cooking utensils, etc. In this way she can continue to offer quality service.

The other members are Maritza a 50 year old exemplary woman who is the owner of a small store and Juana who is 37 years old and from her house has been selling ice-cream, ice and soft drinks for the past 8 years.

loans.use: to buy basic grains.

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Kokou Etienne un homme de 38ans se bat chaque fois pour apporter son bien - être à sa famille(femme et 01 enfant de 10ans scolarisé). Il est revendeur de peintures et désire un premier crédit pour acheter plus de marchandises afin de satisfaire les besoins des clients. Il souhaite devenir grossiste et aider son enfant à évoluer dans ses études.
texts.en:
Kokou Etienne is 38 years old and works hard each day to provide for his family's well-being (he has a wife and 10-year-old child who attends school).

He works selling paints and wishes to have this first loan, so he can buy more merchandise and satisfy his customer's needs.

He wishes to become a wholesaler and help his child develop in his studies.

loans.use: to buy paint

loans.name: Raja'

texts.en:
Raja' is 46 years old and married with eight sons. She works with her husband raising sheep and they work hard together to provide their family with the best living conditions. Raja's family was affected by the war in Gaza and her house damaged.

Raja' is requesting a loan to rebuild the walls and ceiling of her home. She will use her loan to purchase cement and remove rubble. Raja' is very grateful to everyone who helps her.

loans.use: to purchase cement, remove rubble, and rebuild her home

loans.name: Silper

texts.en:
Silper is 42 years old. She is married to Peter, and together they have been blessed with five children of 9, 12, 13, 16, and 22.

She sells cereals as well as second hand clothes, businesses she has done for the last five years, earning her a monthly income of 30,000 KES. 

Silper has requested her first loan with VisionFund Kenya of 20,000 KES which she will use to increase her stock of cereals, such as dry maize, millet, beans, etc. to sell.

With the anticipated profits, she will be able to expand her businesses further. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cereals

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is a 25-year-old secondhand clothing trader. He is a married father of two children whose spouse is a housewife hence does not supply additional income for her family.

Mohammed sells second-hand clothes,a business he has done for the last two years earning good income.

This marks his second borrowing from VisionFund Kenya after repaying his first loan well. He will use the loan to purchase a bale of secondhand clothes for resale and use the anticipated profit to expand his business further. 

He hopes to become a wholesale supplier of secondhand clothes in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase a bales of secondhand clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 27 years old and supports six family members. She has been selling maize grains in the market for the last two years and the business earns her KES 9,000 per month. 

She has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow. |This will enable her to make milk sales, and through the income earned, she will be able to restock her maize and meet her customers' demands.

Catherine plans to use the generated profits to repay her loan and educate her children. 

Her future hope is to eradicate poverty in her family and have a stable family.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Edwinah

texts.en:
Edwinah is 38 years old, married and is blessed with 3 children who are all in school. She sells fish, a business she has been doing for the last 5 years. 

Edwinah has requested for her first loan which she will use to purchase more stock of fish to sell to her customers, with the hope that this will enable her to educate her children and expand her business.

Edwinah's future hopes are to expand her fish selling business, make more income and to be able to support her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of fish to sell to her customers, with the hope that this will enable her to educate her children and expand her business

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 51 years old. He is married to Gladys and together they have been blessed with six children aged between 20 and 6 years old.

George sells cereals, and this is a business he has done for the last 10 years, earning a monthly income of KES 20,000. He has requested his second loan with VisionFund Kenya of KES. 30,000, which he will use to buy dried cereals like maize, beans, cow peas and lentils.He successfully repaid his previous loan.

With the anticipated profits from his business, George will be able to expand his business further as well as repay his loan. 

His hopes and dream for the future is continually to grow his business inorder to become sustainable..

loans.use: to buy dried cereals

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee is 71 years old. She is married with two children aged 11 and 29 years. 1 of them goes to school. She is a farmer and has been growing maize for the past 45 years. Her husband is also a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees of her children and to renovate her house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Cansilde

texts.en:
Cansilde is aged 33 years old. She is married with two children aged between 4 months and 2 years.The do not yet go to school. She is a farmer, and she has been growing maize for the past 15 years, while her husband is a farmer also. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested the maize production. The profits from the business will be used to pay medical insurance.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more tomatoes, onions and beans to sell.

loans.name: Ntawunziyandemye

texts.en:
Ntawunziyandemye is 34 years old. He is married with two children, who are two and eight years old. One of them goes to school. Ntawunziyandemye is a farmer and has been growing maize for the past 18 years. His wife is also a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a piece of land and to improve his welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Epaphrodite

texts.en:
Epaphrodite is 39 years old. He is married and has four children aged between 4 and 14 years. They all go to school. 

He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 20 years, while his husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested the maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees of his children and to pay medical insurance.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow so as to increase the supply of milk to meet the increased demand within the community, and hence, meet family demands.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is forty years old. She is a single mother of five children. She runs a school and has been in business for five years. Her monthly income is four thousand Kenya shillings

This is her second loan with VisionFund Kenya LTD. She plans to use the entire loan to buy desks for the pupils.

She plans to use the profits to pay for medical care and school fees for her children. In the future, she aspires to expand her business and raise the family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to buy school desks.

loans.name: Donathile

texts.en:
Donathile is 33 years old. She is married with 4 children aged between 3 and 11 years, 3 of them go to school. She is a farmer and he has been growing rice for the past 14 years. Her husband is also a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers and pay school fees for her children. The profits from the business will be used to improve her welfare and to buy a house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pay her children's school fees.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: Justine is 44 years old. She is a widow. She sells clothes and she has been in business for the past 12 yearS. With the loan, she would like to buy more clothes to sell. The profits from the business will be used to renovate her house. In the future, she aims to earn at least 500,000 RWF per month.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 26-year-old hardworking man with two children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He owns a motorcycle transport business, which he started with a hope of employing himself.

He has a vision of building rentals that will bring him more income despite the setback of high fuel prices. Charles intends to use the loan to help him buy iron sheets to build rentals.

loans.use: to buy iron sheets to build rentals.

loans.name: Sincere (2) Group

texts.en:
Twelve years ago, Romio started up his own business as a barber in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo. Having started with HOPE Congo back in 2012, he is returning for his 6th loan with HOPE and has requested an amount of 825,000 XAF. In addition to his barber shop, Romio also sells drinks to his customers and will use the loan to purchase a larger variety of imported drinks for his shop. 

Romio is a member of the community bank Sincere (2) and leads 5 other member of his group. With the expansion of his business, Romio hopes to build a house for his family and to visit other markets and countries, along with providing a solid education for his children. He hopes to accomplish this vision by expanding his drink business to sell as a wholesaler and by opening a more modern hair salon in his neighborhood.

loans.use: to purchase drinks and supplies for his barber shop and general store.

loans.name: Bintihamed

texts.en:
Bintihamed is a married mother of two children who do not go to school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is and daily household needs.

For over four years Bintihamed has sold food outside her home to her neighbors and passersby. Her biggest challenge is seasonality.

Bintihamed decided to join Yehu to access the loans offered to improve her business. She is applying for a 40,000 KES loan to buy wheat and maize flour, tea leaves and cooking fat.

loans.use: to buy wheat and maize flour, tea leaves and cooking fat.
